ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed better skills to advocate for my art and be able to have discussions about my practice. This was something I had a lot of trouble around and talking to so many professional artists made it feel much less scary and also I discovered that I have a lot of commonality with some artists and how they think about things.
The course is a requirement for the Art senior cohort, so it's a space for us to get to know each others' work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Straightforward class. Each class is dedicated to a couple of students who would give presentations about their senior thesis. We would then give feedback. It's a helpful class in terms of directing your thesis and I feel like I got what I needed out of it. The multitude of opportunities for studio visits from guest critics was nice. The only annoying parts were administrative things, like getting swipe access, figuring out studio spaces, etc.

course information was not easily accessible 
Course structure was not well organized

The biggest strength is getting to know the other art major seniors and their practices. However, this thesis class ideally would not be on Fridays at 9:25 am, as it is quite early for seniors who usually don't have other classes on Friday and have society on Thursday late nights.
We did not have access to our studios for the first part of the semester but the presentations were very generative and no two people are doing remotely the same thing which is amazing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is the sort of class where you either have to take it, or you can't take it, so I don't know if it's worth much to say whether I "recommend" it, but here's the run down of what we did in the class: For most of the semester, we watched presentations from each art major on their work so far and their plans for their thesis. We asked questions and made suggestions. Because each presentation was 30 min (15 minutes of presenting and 15 minutes for questions/discussion) we did an average of 3 people per class. We had about 27(!) people in the class, so this took us most of the semester. Then, in the last three weeks of the semester, we met in the gallery during this period and had final crits with visiting artists.
